content:
Per poter inquadrare il problema prova a fornire queste informazioni:

  1. Versione di Thunderbird
  2. Versione del sistema operativo
  3. Provider delle caselle email (Gmail, Libero, Hotmail, etc.)
  4. Tipologia di account (POP3, IMAP)
  5. Estensioni installate
  6. Messaggi di errore che vengono visualizzati durante l'utilizzo di Thunderbird
  7. Software di sicurezza eventualmente presenti (Antivirus e simili)
  8. Screenshot del problema (se utile a chiarire il contesto)
creator: @next

content:
KROK 1: Zkontrolujte heslo mimo Thunderbird. Zkuste se přihlásit do své e-mailové schránky přes webový prohlížeč (např. Gmail, Centrum, Seznam, Outlook…). Pokud heslo nefunguje ani tam, problém je v účtu samotném → je potřeba obnovit heslo na webu poskytovatele. Pokud funguje přes web, pokračujte níže.

KROK 2: Odstraňte staré uložené heslo v Thunderbirdu. Otevřete Thunderbird. V menu klikněte na Nástroje → Možnosti (nebo Nastavení). Otevřete sekci Soukromí a zabezpečení → Uložená hesla. Najděte tam heslo k vašemu e-mailovému účtu a klikněte na Odstranit. Zavřete nastavení. Při příštím odesílání/přijímání e-mailu vás Thunderbird znovu vyzve k zadání hesla → zadejte správné heslo.

KROK 3: Zkontrolujte nastavení serverů (SMTP a IMAP/POP) V Thunderbirdu: Menu → Nastavení účtů → Nastavení serveru Zkontrolujte: Název serveru (např. imap.gmail.com, pop3.seznam.cz, imap.centrum.cz) Port (IMAP: 993, POP3: 995, SMTP: 465 nebo 587) Zabezpečení připojení: SSL/TLS Metoda ověření: „Normální heslo“ nebo „OAuth2“ (záleží na poskytovateli) V části Server odchozí pošty (SMTP) zkontrolujte totéž.
creator: Ansamb

content:
Come ho detto sopra: se IMAP è utilizzato su tutti i PC, la posta è sincronizzata ed ogni azione che si fa su uno qualsiasi dei computer viene replicata su tutti gli altri.

Assicurati che la configurazione sia IMAP ed usi le stesse impostazioni su tutti i PC.
creator: @next

content:
That sounds more than frustrating, but please remember, using capitals implies you are shouting at the very people you are asking for help and they did not cause the problem you are experiencing.

It is important to compact folders on a regular basis as it cleans up traces of old previously deleted or moved emails. If you do not do this then files become significantly larger then you expect and the risk of file corruption is increased. Ideally a manual compaction on Inbox, Spam and Drafts should be done after deleting a load of emails or moving a load of emails. Corruption can also occur if you allow Anti-Virus products access to scanning your profile folders. Any file that gets opened may be scanned and if it does not like anything in that file - it can cause havoc.

It is exceptionally unusual to lose all emails in all folders in an account. So let's try to find out what's going on and what is currently stored in profile.

Please supply some information so we can understand your setup.

Q: What OS do you use ? Windows 11, MAC, Linux ? Q: Did you get the installation/download of Thunderbird from the official Thunderbird website or did you get it from the Windows app store or somewhere else ?

Q: What Anti-Virus do you use and is it allowed to scan all folders? That means it also scans any file on computer that gets opened and scan any file that gets downloaded etc?

Q: Are you talking about an IMAP or POP account? Q: Can you still see all the folders and subfolders in the effected account ? OR are they also missing ? Q: If you can see the folders - do they look like they are using an italic font ?

Check what is on server: Please logon to your webmail account via a browser. Q: Can you still see all the emails on the server?

Now to find out what is stored in the Profile folders... In Thunderbird

  • Help > Troubleshooting Information
  • Under 'Application Basics' - about half way down is 'Profile Folder' - click on 'Open Folder' button

A new window opens showing the contents of you 'profile name' folder.

If you are talking about a POP account:

  • Select the 'Mail' folder to see contents
  • Select the name of the pop account folder to see contents.

If you are talking about an IMAP account:

  • Select the 'ImapMail' folder to see contents
  • Select the name of the imap account folder to see contents.

Make sure the View is showing Details, so everything is in columns. Make sure you have the Name, Modified Date, Type and Size columns

Post images showing all the information you see. Make sure you include the directory path, so I know where you are looking. You might need to post/ upload several images. They must be image files eg: .jpg If you see folders with a .sbd extension, then select the folder and post image which shows it's contents.

I'm now following this question, so will look out for your response. Please note, you may also get others who may try to assist as well.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
This issue has effected some people and has been reported as a bug. Bug report just in case you wanted to follow it:

  • https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1990571

It seems to effect those who have a deeper hierachy of folders and subfolders OR/AND may have installed Thunderbird from the 'Windows app store' which does not use the standard location, so is much longer.

Thunderbird downloaded from: https://www.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/all/ Uses the following as a default location for profile:

  • C://Users/<username>/Appdata/Roaming/Thunderbird/Profiles/<profile name>/ etc

Thunderbrd installed from the 'Windows App Store' uses the following as a default location for profile:

  • C://Users/<username>/AppData/Local/Packages/MozillaThunderbird.MZLA_h5892qc0xkpca/LocalCache/Roaming/Thunderbird/Profiles/<profile name>/ etc


Advise at the moment is to try the following first as it has worked for others. Look at the various folder names and see if you can rename to use less characters. Especially for any folders with subfolders that seem effected. Example senarios:

  • Folder name: 'Online Orders' rename as 'Orders' - this will save 7 chararcter as a space is also deemed as a character.
  • Folder name: 'Marks and Spencer' rename as 'M&S' - saving 14 chars
  • Folder name : 'Thunderbird Support' rename as 'TBird Help' or even just 'TBird'
creator: Toad-Hall

creator: Toad-Hall

content: Try this: - click help>troubleshootinginformation - scroll down to 'Profiles' in left column and click 'about:profiles' - the next pane should list all profiles available. Click the 'open' button to view profile contents. The addressbook consists of two files: abook.sqlite and history.sqlite - if you look in the inactive profile and the size s bigger than the one in the default profile, then you have discovered your addressbook. Note the file location. - now, return to thunderbird and click tools>import>import from a file and follow the menus for addressbook until the select of file type appears. Click the sqlite option and then select the abook.sqlite file from where you located it. Repeat the steps for the history.sqlite file

content: I don't think this is a Unified issue, since that is just a way of viewing accounts in a combined virtual folder. Do you have the account as POP on another device? That could be downloading from the Inbox and deleting from the server, the default POP setting, making it appear the messages have been moved from the IMAP Inbox.

content: The IMAP and POP accounts are on the same server and both reside on the Mac. The server name is either IMAP.sonic.net or POP.sonic.net. The IMAP account checks for new messages once a minute; on the POP account none of the five server settings boxes are checked. The POP account "waking up" would explain what I'm seeing since messages in the IMAP inbox that were tagged have no tag when they show up in the POP inbox.
